Literature Review: Bacteriophages, or phages, have long been recognized as a significant challenge in the dairy industry, particularly in large-scale commercial fermentations. These viruses that infect bacteria have been a persistent threat to the production of fermented dairy products, causing substantial economic losses and compromising product quality. This literature review aims to explore recent advances in understanding phage-host interactions, mechanisms of phage resistance, and their implications for the dairy industry and future food fermentations.Lactic acid bacteria (LAB) are essential in dairy fermentations, serving as starter cultures for various products. However, these bacteria are susceptible to phage infections, which can lead to fermentation failures and inconsistent product quality. The coevolution of LAB and their associated phages has been a subject of intense study in recent years, providing valuable insights into the dynamics of these interactions.Marcó et al. (2012) conducted a comprehensive review of phage-host interactions in LAB, highlighting the diversity of phage resistance mechanisms employed by different bacterial species. These mechanisms include prevention of phage adsorption, inhibition of DNA injection, restriction-modification systems, and CRISPR-Cas adaptive immunity. The authors emphasized the importance of understanding these mechanisms for developing more robust starter cultures.The location of phage resistance genes, whether on chromosomes or plasmids, has significant implications for the development of phage-resistant strains. Mahony et al. (2016) explored the genetic basis of phage resistance in Streptococcus thermophilus, a key species in yogurt and cheese production. They found that many phage resistance mechanisms in this species are plasmid-encoded, facilitating their transfer between strains and potentially accelerating the development of resistant cultures.Recent advances in genomics and bioinformatics have revolutionized our understanding of phage-host interactions. Garneau and Moineau (2011) reviewed the impact of these technologies on phage biology and discussed how they have enabled the identification of novel phage resistance mechanisms and improved our ability to predict phage-host ranges.The dairy industry has implemented various strategies to mitigate the impact of phages on fermentations. Rotation of starter cultures has been a common practice, but its effectiveness can be limited by the rapid evolution of phages. Muhammed et al. (2017) evaluated the efficacy of different starter rotation strategies and proposed optimized approaches based on phage-host population dynamics.In recent years, there has been growing interest in exploiting phage-host interactions for beneficial purposes in the dairy industry. Rodríguez-Rubio et al. (2015) explored the potential use of phage-derived proteins as biocontrol agents against pathogenic bacteria in dairy products. This approach represents a novel strategy for improving food safety while potentially reducing the use of chemical preservatives.The development of phage-resistant starter cultures has been a major focus of research and industrial efforts. Coughlan et al. (2016) reviewed various approaches to engineering phage resistance in LAB, including the use of CRISPR-Cas systems and the exploitation of natural phage resistance mechanisms. They highlighted the potential of these strategies to create more robust and versatile starter cultures for the dairy industry.As the food industry evolves, there is increasing interest in plant-based alternatives to dairy products. Interestingly, the knowledge gained from studying phage-host interactions in dairy fermentations is proving valuable in this emerging field. Kot et al. (2019) discussed how insights from dairy phage research could be applied to fermentations involving plant-based substrates, potentially guiding the development of new products and processes.While significant progress has been made in understanding and mitigating the impact of phages in dairy fermentations, challenges remain. Mahony et al. (2017) highlighted the ongoing arms race between phages and their bacterial hosts, emphasizing the need for continued research and innovation in this field. They argued that a deeper understanding of phage-host coevolution is crucial for developing long-term solutions to phage-related problems in the dairy industry.In conclusion, the threat posed by bacteriophages to dairy fermentations has driven significant advances in our understanding of phage-host interactions and bacterial defense mechanisms. While the problem is not entirely solved, the dairy industry now has a range of tools and strategies at its disposal to mitigate the impact of phages on fermentations. Moreover, the knowledge gained from this field is poised to benefit other areas of food fermentation, including the emerging sector of plant-based alternatives. As research continues to unravel the complexities of phage-host interactions, it is likely that even more effective solutions will be developed, further transforming the landscape of food fermentations.
